newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Asian Sugar - China gov't buying seen aiding price.
newsitem.headline: Asian Sugar - China gov't buying seen aiding price.

text.p: The Chinese government's move to buy sugar and support wilting domestic prices was having a small effect in some parts of the country but no dramatic price shifts were expected, sugar industry sources said on Wednesday.
"The sugar price has gone up by about 50 yuan (US$6) because of the policy," a factory source said by telephone from China's southern sugar-producing province of Guangxi.
He said the average price of sugar in Guangxi was still around 3,800 yuan per tonne.
China's Ministry of Internal Trade issued a circular last month to government sugar firms nationwide to buy sugar to boost reserves and bolster flagging domestic sugar prices.
"If the prices do not go up further and continue to slide, the government may buy another 400,000 tonnes of sugar," the factory source said.
Hong Kong and China sugar traders agreed that no spectacular shifts in the domestic price of sugar would take place in the rest of February.
"It's pretty dull," said a Hong Kong trader.
A trader in Japan said China may step into the market if domestic sugar prices firmed to 4,500 or 4,600 yuan per tonne.
Views on China's sugar imports were contradictory.
One trader reported a 20,000-22,000 tonne cargo, probably from Thailand or Australia, arriving at the southern port of Shekou last month.
Another China-based source said a cargo had been turned away by customs at a southern port, but no further details were available.
Neither report could be confirmed.

China's reduced temporary import tariff on raw sugar to 12 percent from 30 percent, announced last week, was primarily to satisfy requirements for World Trade Organisation membership, a China-based sugar source said.
"It's good for imports but bad for factories," the source said, noting that increased imports would depress already ailing domestic prices.
Indonesian buying continued at a healthy clip and purchases of another 300,000-400,000 tonnes could come in the short term, a Hong Kong trader said.
Asian sugar markets remained quiet, although market players slowly returned from the Lunar New Year holidays, traders in Japan said.
Thai raw sugar premiums had firmed slightly but little business was done so far, they said.

Thai premiums for March/May delivery were quoted at 0.20/0.30 cents (bid/offer) per pound over New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on an FOB (free on board) basis, compared with 0.20/0.25 a week ago, they said.
May/July deliveries were quoted at 0.30/0.45 cents over the New York exchange, up from 0.30 cents the previous week. July/September deliveries were at 0.50 cents.

The traders said firmer premiums were mainly attributable to small-lot physical buying and position adjustments, but added that the premiums were likely to ease amid slack physical demand in the region.

"I don't think China will enter the market before May this year," a trader at a major trade house said. "It appears that China has ample stocks, and China's domestic sugar price is still too low for the country to buy," he said.
-- Mishi Saran in Hong Kong (852) 2843 6358
-- Keiko Takagi in Tokyo (813) 3432 7391
